Sophie Christiansen has just heard we want to take a photo of her. "Well I'm not looking very glamorous, am I?" She looks at Pippa, her publicist/helper/dresser/bodyguard. "You'll have to help with my hair," says the triple gold medal-winning equestrian before manoeuvring herself into her diasability scooter and whizzing across the media lounge.

We're at Team GB House, just across the road from the Olympic park, where Britain's medallists come to be feted. As it happens, her friend and fellow equestrian, Natasha Baker, is being interviewed about her second gold medal win. "Tash!" Christiansen shouts with delight, and starts singing along to Spandau Ballet's Gold. The interviewer spots Christiansen. "And I do believe we have Sophie in the house," he announces. A huge roar follows. Her face splits into a smile of pure joy.

Christiansen is still only 24, and she's a five-time Paralympic gold medallist. "An old woman!" she says. Her story is astonishing. She was born two months premature with cerebral palsy. From a desperate start, things got worse. She had a fit and then suffered from jaundice, blood poisoning, and a collapsed lung. Oh, and she had a heart attack. Few expected her to survive.

But she didn't just survive, she thrived. By six she was riding horses, and excelling at school. At 16 she won a bronze at the Athens Paralympics in the most disabled category of dressage. In Beijing, at 20, she won two golds and a silver. And now she's topped that.

Her body is floppy, her muscles spasm involuntarily, her speech is slurred, and she is utterly lovely – funny, gobby, brainy, heroic. She tells me about her background – her teacher parents, younger brother Alex, how they grew up near Ascot. Ah, I say, so that explains the horses. "No. Pure coincidence. In fact my mum is allergic to horses." She pauses. "I just took it up to annoy her." She creases up, laughing. Perhaps the most miraculous thing is that, despite struggling so much to control her body, she has excelled in a sport that is all about perfect control. "Yes, precision," she says, precisely. Dressage is also known as horse ballet – two-legged and four-legged partner walk and trot to music in perfect time and rhythm.

How does she manage it? "Dressage comes from the French 'dresser', which means to train and that's what it's about; training the horse. So we train my horse to do what he's suppposed to do – no matter what I'm doing. Rio knows he just has to walk in the correct rhythm and stay relaxed. Sometimes due to my disability I do give the wrong signals, but he's trained to almost ignore that."

Rio is better known as Janeiro. He has two names – a formal competition name, and a nickname for intimates. In this Paralympics, the pair have improvised brilliantly with the accompanying music – as well as Land of Hope and Glory and Pink Floyd, their routine included Big Ben's chimes and a quotation from Shakespeare. "I'm quite into my music. I go to a lot of gigs." What's her favourite piece in the routines? "Another Brick in the Wall. It was quite ironic because I've got a master's degree in maths."

Why's that ironic? "Because it's: 'We don't need no education.' And I used it because I hope the Paralympics will educate people in disability, and also inspire them to go out and achieve their dream, no matter how difficult it is."

At times, she says, it has been very difficult. Her parents fought for her to go to a mainstream school with a special unit attached. They were absolutely right, too, she says. It gave her the best of both worlds – support and the chance to integrate. Still, integrating wasn't easy. I tell her that when I was a child I went to a special school, and the able-bodied pupils were horrible to those with cerebral palsy. She nods. "I think every kid goes through a bit of that, disabled or able-bodied." A bit of what? "A bit of what I suppose you'd call bullying."

But isn't it different if the bullying is about your cerebral palsy?

"Yes. But I didn't get that much name-calling. Making friends was the most difficult thing for me. I was quite shy because of my speech. Also at lunch I didn't have much time to go out and play because it took me longer to eat. Until GCSEs I didn't have many friends."

Going to Athens for the Paralympics in 2004 changed everything. She came back, she says, a different person. "Because I won a bronze medal at such a young age I had to talk to a lot of media, do a lot of interviews, and it really brought me out of myself. I had to become less self-conscious, and after that, at sixth form, I had a great friend."

Are people with cerebral palsy stereotyped? "I think we used to be." In what way? "That we'd just stay at home doing nothing. I still get it now." She laughs, points her index finger to her head and makes a screw-loose motion. "Because of my speech people think I'm not all there. Some people come up and start talking through my friend to me, and I am like, 'Excuse me, I am here.' When they think I'm mentally disabled, I try to drop in the conversation that I got a first-class masters degree in maths."

Was she always a mathematical genius? "I always liked maths! I wouldn't call myself a genius. It didn't come easy to me. The key is I work very hard in everything I do."

Has she got a favourite equation? "Fermat's theorem," she answers instantly. "Xn + Yn = Zn. I like the story behind it. Fermat was a French mathematician from, I think, the 17th century. You may have to check your facts on this. [She's right, of course.] And he claimed to have proved the theorem. He wrote it down in a book that he'd proved it, but no one could actually find his proof, so for centuries mathematicians have been trying to prove it to see whether he actually did prove it. Then a few years ago it was finally proven, by a guy named Andrew Wiles."

As she explains, I'm staring at the three gold medals around her neck. She looks magnificently bling – the Liz Taylor of the Paralympics. What does it feel like to wear them all at once? "Heavy," she complains. "No, it's the most amazing feeling ever. Normally I think I'm just me, I just do what I do. But when everybody else acknowledges it, it comes back that I have achieved something special."

Isn't it ridiculous winning three golds? Yes, she says, in a way, but that was the target she set herself. "I knew my horse was capable of it. It was just down to me to get it out of him." Who deserves the medal more, her or Rio? "Half and half. He has been the perfect partner for me. I couldn't have wished for a better horse."

But they had a tough start, and just being selected for the Paralympics was a struggle. "Last year, my old horse Rivaldo went lame the day before we were meant to go to the Europeans. A couple of weeks later he got put down. I'd already got Rio a couple of months before as my backup, but then I had to bring him on and form a partnership much quicker than I had intended to."

Even though she felt she was riding well, the results were disappointing. So she looked at the possible reasons. "And I think the main thing was that I was so desperate to get to the Paralympics, and my desperation was transferring through to Rio in competition. So I worked really hard with my psychologist."

And the work paid off. She says she has had the most fantastic few weeks, and has never been involved in anything like this before – the crowds, the enthusiasm, the way disabled people have been empowered and embraced.

What's most surprising, I say, is that this has happened in a city where disabled people are virtually invisible because facilities for them are so poor.

She nods, and looks at Pippa. "I'm not sure if I'm allowed to give my opinion on this, but I'm going to anyway. Public transport has improved with the games because there were so many volunteers around to put out ramps and stuff." But she says, normally, it's nothing like this. "I've been stranded by myself on a train many times with no one … even if I book it, which you have to do 24 hours in advance. So you can't be spontaneous. People are great, if they see you're stuck anywhere, they'll come and help you." But that's people, not systems, I say. "Yeah, yeah, I'm getting there! But access is horrendous in London, and we're meant to be the world leader in everything. It's rubbish." If she were a politician, what would she want to do for disabled people? "Well, the Paralympics has improved London transport in terms of the number of helpers. But in terms of actual physical access, they haven't done anything. I went to Vienna at New Year and their underground system was amazing. The tube would come up, the platform would level with the carriage and a little ramp would come out of the carriage. It really put London to shame."

What does she think about the fact that we're celebrating disability, and yet at the same time the government is looking to cut disability benefits? "From my point of view, I've got a job now [as a statistician]. But getting that job was really difficult. With my first-class masters degree, I wanted to get a high-flying job in the City. And I went to loads of interviews and ended up thinking, this isn't going to work. Firstly, I wouldn't be able to live in London because of access, and secondly, the big companies weren't willing to give me a bit of extra help. For example, I couldn't go on a placement for a week in Edinburgh because I needed to take a carer with me."

The thing is, she reckons, businesses would gain if they employed more disabled people. "The general feeling among the employees would be, 'Well, if they can do it, we can too.' So even if I might be slower to do the actual physical job, it would motivate others to do their work." So, other workers would say, 'Well if somebody disabled can make a good job of it, so can I'? "Yes." She giggles at her fabulously un-PC theory. "Well that's my opinion." What does she think about the fact that Atos, which sponsors the Paralympics, is also the company the government has appointed to weed out disability claimant fraudsters? Another knowing smile. "I don't think I can answer that! I don't know a lot about that story." Has she come across such cheats? "No. I haven't seen it."

Look, she says, the Paralympics have already changed so much, and now it's up to everybody to build on that. "I'm still in a bit of a bubble. I don't think it will hit me just how much we've affected the nation until I get out of here."

One thing is for sure, though, she's going to have plenty to occupy her – the statistician job, training for her next dressage championship, and now campaigning. As Pippa helps her on to her scooter, Christiansen waves a hand at me – a farewell and a promise.

"I'll be out talking to politicians about all this!"

As someone who loves to drive, I've long agreed with my fellow ageing car-freak PJ O'Rourke's tersely grouchy opinion of bicycles and, by extension, their riders: "Bicycles are childish," he opined in a 1980s essay, before upping the ante considerably, to "bicycles are un-American."

Even O'Rourke, however, might change his curmudgeonly tune upon seeing Premium Rush, a very serviceable little bicycle-based thriller, and a kinetic crowd-pleaser possessed of all the honourable B-movie values: tautness and compactness, enough plot to keep you guessing and some impressive stunts and collisions. It also has a time-crunch aspect: bike messenger Joseph Gordon-Levitt must ferry a nondescript envelope across town in 90 minutes, dodging cabbies, pile-ups, and a vicious cop (Michael Shannon) with "impulse-control issues".

Although it's not strictly speaking a real-time movie, the time-crunch does put one in mind of other no less enjoyable bubblegum thrillers like Speed, Nick Of Time and Phone Booth. That list is also reminiscent of the good choices Gordon-Levitt has made in transition from child star to movie star.

He likes B-thrillers and thoughtful dramas. Some of his movies, like The Lookout and Brick, are both, while Mysterious Skin, Stop-Loss and (500) Days Of Summer prove that he either gets the first look at the best scripts, or that he just has excellent taste in projects (much like Michelle Williams). It's nice to see, even as he ascends into superstardom, that between mega-projects like Inception and The Dark Knight Rises, he's happy to squeeze in smaller projects like Premium Rush and 50/50.

Compared to a lot of these movies, Premium Rush is like a day-off, a good-time movie for all involved, including, thankfully, the viewer. One link with Speed can be found in Rush's villain, played by Michael Shannon. Shannon's work has always been interesting, from his sexually repressed T-Man in Boardwalk Empire to his Oscar nomination for Revolutionary Road, but here he tries something like menace plus comedy, and the result recalls Dennis Hopper's over-the-top villain in Speed. That's a dubious compliment, I realise, since Shannon is a fine actor and Hopper, to my mind, was a terrible one. But as the only player on screen who's really working up a sweat (as a thespian, that is, not as a cyclist), it's odd that he finally should come off – as Hopper often did – so much like one of the guys they pull the masks off at the end of Scooby-Doo.

Top-table screenwriter David Koepp directed, and on the basis of this and his creepy ghost thriller Stir Of Echoes, he should write less and direct a lot more, because who really needs Jurassic Park 4? In the meantime, though, bicycles just became marginally less childish and un-American.

The Pirates! In An Adventure With Scientists!

People bang on about how great Pixar are, but often ignore that with Aardman the UK has an animation studio that equals it in talent, scope and quality control. The Pirates! is a world-class piece of entertainment, with talented animators bringing their A-game to the table – literally, as most stop-motion animation is executed on table-top sets.

It's a rollicking tale of a band of pleasant pirates and their well-intentioned but ineffectual captain (played by Hugh Grant). Maybe it's because he's off camera, but Grant has never sounded as relaxed, confident and funny as here. With the animators putting his character's puppet body through moves broader and bolder than the actor would ever do in life, they have collaborated to somehow deliver the best Grant performance possible. They embark on an adventure that takes in most of the seven seas and involves a weaselish Charles Darwin, the last Dodo and an evil Queen Victoria. The level of detail is incredible, with some sort of gag in nigh-on every shot, be it in dialogue, movement or set dressing.

Like all the best children's entertainment, The Pirates! is a film that demands several viewings, and youngsters will come back to it in later years to notice things that sailed completely over their head when they first saw it.

Before someone you know gets seriously ill, you tend to think that medicine consists of absolutes. Right answers. Perfect prescriptions. Broken bones fused so you never feel a twinge. But since my dad developed vascular dementia, I've realised that opinions differ, mistakes are made. Sometimes you have to decide yourself what might be for the best.

There are so many grey areas; you long for certainties, branches to cling on to. Take Dad's diagnosis, for example. We all knew something was wrong. His short-term memory was shot. He flanked any conversation with bizarre non-sequiturs. He kept losing his car, taking the hinges off doors and dismantling appliances at night in the house where he lived alone. He'd leave 10 rambling messages in a row on our mobiles and then cheerily ring again, as if for the first time.

Yet getting the medical authorities to concede there really was something going on was nigh on impossible.

Part of me knows that's how it occasionally has to be. Sometimes it's better not to label the no-man's land between health and illness, especially when it involves an individual's loss of freedom. And confidentiality is important – there is only so far that concerned family members can go in expressing opinions.

However, I still don't think anyone spent enough time properly appraising him or taking our worries seriously. There needs to be a hand there to catch those who are freefalling.

Dad was always charming, full of stories. When the consultant came to assess him at home, finally referred by the GP, Dad just spun his usual web of yarns. Made tea. Covered up the holes in his head. The doctor said he seemed fine. He'd been through a bit of stress lately, perhaps it was that. To be on the safe side, he referred him for tests for Alzheimer's, which came back negative, of course, as the form of dementia Dad suffers from is vascular. So he was deemed capable.

A few months later, things were worse. Dad kept visiting the police station and the hospital. I think, heart-breakingly, he wanted someone in authority to help, to stop the confusion in his head. By then his house was freezing as he'd attacked his boiler and gouged out the lock on his front door. If we got it fixed, he would break it again the very next night. So the consultant came again and did the same questionnaire. This time the diagnosis was "probable vascular dementia".

I find that "probable" infuriating, even now. I just don't understand the room for doubt, when he was patently so poorly. And if it was there, why couldn't someone have just spent a bit more time with him to make sure?

I know the NHS is strapped. I appreciate the need for caution. But it might have prevented those frightening months when Dad spun so badly out of control. It might have stopped all those hours he spent zooming around country lanes in his snazzy red Citroën, when it wasn't safe to do so. It could have prevented the time he nearly slipped into hypothermia under a thin blanket on a particularly icy night in his lonely house by the sea.

It seems hard to believe, but that was only two and a half years ago. His deterioration has been so complete, that recalling our uncertainty over whether he was ill seems laughable.

But now the diagnosis is incontrovertible, other ambiguities persist. Should he be started on anti-psychotic pills or will they damage his weak heart? Does the Valium help to make him calmer or just zonk him out? Just how often is he having those mini-strokes that peg his decline?

The scary thing is that I'm not sure there are any right answers. But that doesn't stop me longing for them.

I was a guest on BBC Women's Hour the other week, and one of the contributors made an interesting remark – an unusual event in itself for WH, but this comment actually got me thinking. She said: "I don't know any woman who doesn't suffer from guilt." I have no way of knowing whether this is true, but it feels plausible. There is, for a modern woman, plenty she can find to feel guilty about. Perhaps the food binge, the shopping splurge, the career woman struggling with maternal guilt. Perhaps the failure of yet another diet, the collapse of another exercise regime, the malicious comment later regretted.

I have rarely come across a man tormented by everyday guilt. Perhaps they just keep it quiet. Either way, guilt is a pernicious business that destroys more than it creates. But no one can ever quite say what it is, which is probably why it is so difficult to shake off.

It is frequently confused with conscience, which is "good" guilt – recognising that you have done something wrong, atoning or apologising for it, and then moving on. Guilt is stickier than this. It seems to find a semi-permanent niche in the psyche of those who are susceptible to it.

People inclined to feelings of guilt – ie feeling bad when they have done nothing wrong in particular – come as several types. There are those who felt as children that they were Bad and are spending the rest of their lives trying to keep this perception at bay. These are the Damaged Guilty. They include people who were mistreated or neglected in some fashion.

Then there are the Ideological Guilty – those whose beliefs about how virtuous they and others should be are unrealistically elevated. The Ideologically Guilty believe that people should be pure, good and beyond reproach. They feel endlessly disappointed with themselves – and other people – when they are confronted with the fact that the default human condition is weakness and flaw. Women, with their cultural patriarchal legacy of being Madonnas (as an alternative to whores), seem to me particularly susceptible to this variety of guilt.

This kind of guilt is largely self-directed, but some people inflict guilt on others to make them miserable – the Guilt Dispensers. The Jewish mother is the classic stereotype for this, but it tends to apply in close-knit families generally. In marriages, Guilt Dispensers often pair up with the Damaged Guilty, thus setting up a power dynamic, with the GD inevitably having the upper hand over the DG. Guilt can make you behave atrociously – not only towards yourself but also towards others. Quite apart from those who work to make other people feel guilty, there are those who punish others in order to evade their own feelings of guilt.

Nevertheless, there are those – the church for instance, and the political establishment – who think we couldn't do without guilt. In this view, guilt is a necessary corrective to hedge against bad or anti-social behaviour. I disagree. Marriages and families would certainly be better without it (which is not to say they would be better without conscience). Guilt appears in proportion to the amount of freewill you think you have, because guilty people think they are responsible for everything. It is a form of control freakery.

I have come to the conclusion that one of a husband's subtlest and most difficult tasks is to save his wife from guilt. This usually means being determined to head off her culturally inherited self-sacrificing Madonna-like instincts and not offering, but insisting that you organise the holiday/pick up the kids/clean the house/(insert unpleasant task here). Being given no choice in the matter saves the oppression guilt brings – and it saves you from the punishment that guilt can so often elicit. I recommend it. One of these days, I might even try it.

Does being uprooted matter? Does being removed from the country in which you were born and where you spent the first years of your life leave an indefinable emotional scar? I don't believe so. Many of the "uprooted" are clearly much happier in their adopted countries than they were in their countries of origin. But making a new home in a completely new environment and a completely new language inevitably influences a person's perceptions, both about him- or herself and about others.

I was born in Jerusalem shortly before the second world war and lived there until I was nearly nine. It would never again be my home.

My parents had met there, both having left Germany soon after Hitler came to power. My mother had had to abandon her legal studies in Berlin when the Nazis decreed that Jews could no longer practise law. My father, at that time already a successful lawyer, was debarred from continuing his career. But they were young and unattached and, like many Jews who could afford to start a new life, they set off for Palestine, where Jews could live freely. They married in 1937.

Neither of them were committed Zionists. On the contrary, my father's experiences in the first world war as a soldier in the German army (he had won an Iron Cross) had put him off all forms of nationalism. My mother, before the rise of Hitler, had been in favour of assimilation, believing that the more Jews and non-Jews intermarried, the more likely it would be that the "Jewish problem" would gradually fade away.

Nor were they religious. In common with many German Jews, they did not observe Jewish customs or traditions in any shape or form. Throughout my childhood I never once entered a synagogue – I barely knew there were such places – and was brought up in ignorance of the most basic tenets of Judaism.

Soon after his arrival in Jerusalem, my father, whose family had been in the retail business, set up a women's fashion store. It was to become the largest such store in the city (which was much smaller in those days). The Queen of Jordan sometimes shopped there. We lived in a large flat above the shop where, as an only child, I spent a great deal of time playing on my own. At home I spoke German and later, at school, Hebrew.

My mother was much stricter than would be acceptable today. During mealtimes, for example, I often had to hold books under my arms to make sure that my elbows weren't sticking out. If I didn't finish my spinach at lunchtime, it would be served up again for supper, with a bit of sugar sprinkled on it.

Not that my childhood in Jerusalem was unhappy. One of my most vivid memories, for example, is of an annual excursion to pick flowers with my adored father. He would take the day off – presumably with the aim of putting in what is now called "quality time" with me – and we would walk hand in hand to the outskirts of town. We would clamber across rocky hills looking for the long-stemmed wild cyclamen – pink, purple and white – that sprang up every year in the patches of dusty earth between the rocks.

We were always alone on this stony high ground, with its panoramic view of the old city surrounded by olive groves. Even as a small child I could sense that there was something historic and mythical in this landscape, or so it seems to me now.

Life at home and at school was going well when, in 1947 (just before the state of Israel came into being), my parents decided to leave Palestine; they were eager to resume their former careers. When we set sail, I thought we were going on holiday. I had no idea that I was never to return – or only years later, as a tourist. I suppose my parents felt that to explain that we were emigrating would upset me too much. So I was not given the chance to say goodbye to my friends, teachers or anyone else.

While my parents travelled to England and America looking for work, they left me in a small boarding school in Switzerland. It was a completely different world and I was overwhelmed by so many new impressions and demands that I soon began to forget my old life. I also began to forget the Hebrew language. When they came to fetch me after a year, I was speaking Swiss-German, which they could barely understand.

Eventually my father was offered an important and very suitable job with an Anglo-American legal aid society to compensate the victims of Nazi persecution. But there was a downside: it meant living in Germany, the last place my parents had wanted to go back to. They reluctantly agreed, but couldn't accept that their daughter should be brought up and educated as a German.

Throughout my childhood my parents never talked to me about the Holocaust. Presumably, they wished to protect me from the knowledge of human evil. Indeed, I gradually deduced, but was never directly told, that my mother's parents had perished in a concentration camp. My mother had travelled back to Germany shortly before the outbreak of war to persuade them to leave but they had refused. A regime as barbaric as Hitler's, they thought, could surely not survive.

My parents wanted me to be English. Like most refugees throughout the world, they greatly admired England – for its tolerance, its independent spirit, its courage in resisting tyranny, its rule of law.

In 1948, my mother went to England to search for a suitable boarding school for me. At that time, many girls' boarding schools did not accept pupils who spoke no English. So she decided on Dartington Hall, the co-educational, "progressive" and somewhat notorious school situated in Devon. She deposited me there and left me to sink or swim.

I sank, temporarily at least. It is a miserable experience to be completely cut off, without a single family member or trusted friend in the whole country to speak to or confide in. Every evening I used to hide in a corner of the school's large, dark gym so that I could cry without being seen.

It took about a year to learn fluent English, after which I soon became an integrated and happy member of the school. Luckily for me, there was a terrific craze for roller-skating a few months after I arrived and because I had learned ice-skating in Switzerland, I was a whizz at this "sport". So my lowly status was slightly enhanced.

Occasionally my parents came to see me, but my chief memory of these visits is the embarrassment I felt because of their German accents. As they had intended, I had been thoroughly anglicised.

In the ensuing years I was too preoccupied – getting married, having children, working – to think much about my childhood in Jerusalem. I did, however, have a rather surprising experience in my thirties, when I went to see the Hollywood epic Exodus. Before this very mediocre film begins, while the credits are rolling, the wide screen is filled with some beautiful panoramic scenes of Jerusalem and its surrounding hills and olive trees. As soon as I saw this, I unexpectedly burst into tears.

Since then, I have only been to Israel for three or four short visits, the most recent of which came about in a most unexpected way. I found myself seated, at a conference, next to a charming Israeli journalist. He was about the same age as me and had also been born in Jerusalem. But talking about our common background turned out to be a uncomfortable experience.

What school had I attended, he asked. Alas, I couldn't remember its name. What about the names of any teachers? Again, sorry, can't remember. OK, surely I could recall the names of some school friends?

Well, yes, I remember the name of one girl, who had been my best friend – Ruth. Ruth what? It was almost exactly 60 years ago, I protested.

"Well," he said, "I regard this as a challenge. I will find your Ruth." He was as good as his word. It took him only a few phone calls.

My Ruth turned out to be a good friend of his. She remembered me well.

A day or two later I got a call from Ruty (as she was known) who sounded so friendly and jolly that I was instantly drawn to her. We decided to email each other our life stories, starting from the time we had last seen each other.

So began an absorbing correspondence, which proceeded by chronological instalments. Every day we would eagerly await the arrival of a new episode and, like Victorian novelists, we sometimes deliberately ended on a cliff-hanger. Our stories could hardly have been more different.

Ruty's life resembled an action thriller. After military service she had worked in various psychiatric centres and addiction clinics; she had founded Israel's first organisation to help dyslexic students and she had worked in the Israeli parliament, becoming head of the foreign relations department. Meanwhile, she had lived through the hardships and terrors of war. My story by contrast, with its succession of desk jobs, was more akin to a romantic novelette.

When our narratives reached the present day, Ruty invited me to Jerusalem, to attend a lunch party she was giving for her women friends. Of course I accepted.

The party was attended by about 30 women – doctors, archaeologists, lawyers, journalists. I have never before, or since, been to a gathering where there was such a strong feeling of mutual trust, openness and equality.

None of the elements which so often impair the enjoyment of social occasions in England – cliquishness, social insecurity, insincerity, and so on – were present. I was hugely impressed and attracted by these women, but at the same time felt very English, and very much an outsider.

The question I was most often asked was: "Why did you leave Israel?"

My reply, that it had been my parents' decision, not mine, seemed not quite to satisfy them. Perhaps I was imagining this – there was certainly nothing reproachful in anyone's reaction – but I felt an unasked question hovering in the air: why hadn't I come back when I was old enough to make my own decisions?

How would I have replied? The truth is that it never occurred to me to return to Israel. I greatly admired the country's achievements – its democratic way of life, its outstanding universities, its cultural attainments, its contributions to medicine and so on – but I had no family or friends there. I had been brought up, for better or worse, without any sense of religious or ethnic identity. Though I have never felt totally at home in England, I married an English husband and had brought up two English children.

I was very happy to be English – or almost English.
